Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
SCH: Workshop on Data Science, Learning, and Applications to Biomedical and Health Sciences

This proposal is for the Transatlantic Data Science Workshop. Due to advances in high throughput and connective computing, medicine is at the cusp of a transformation that will accelerate discovery, improve patient outcomes, decrease costs, and address the complexity of challenging health problems. A main thrust of this transformation requires the use of novel computing and statistical methods to model complex disease trajectories using health data. Unfortunately, access to quality health data is not obvious to non-health and medical science researchers. In addition to lack of access, significant challenges exist in the analysis of 'big data' in the health domain. Investigators in the fields of computer science, mathematics, statistics, and computational sciences may offer expertise in addressing said challenges. This workshop brings together members of multiple scientific communities from the United States (NSF and National Institutes of Health: NIH) and the United Kingdom (Research Council of the United Kingdom: RCUK) and has two primary objectives: 1) to improve access to US and UK health data and to expose challenges surrounding health data research to computer science, mathematics, statistics, and computational science communities, and 2) to foster the development of novel computational and mathematics methodologies in health data science research by bringing together US and UK communities of health domain experts and computational researchers.

The Transatlantic Data Science Workshop includes facilitating the development of novel computational approaches in the health domain using data from two major health data funding agencies (RCUK and NIH). The computational community will be exposed to the challenges and needs in health data research, resulting in opportunities to advance data science research. Analytics challenges surrounding health data research may include data quality and provenance, search, query processing, and visualization and modeling. The first day of the workshop will be devoted to an in-depth exploration of the challenges that are experienced in conducting health data research with six major health datasets. The second day will offer an opportunity for researchers to work in small groups to discuss and develop novel computational techniques and methodologies to tackle such challenges in the health domain. The proposed workshop should aid in the development of novel computational techniques to address challenges in health data research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

The need for a significant transformation of health and medicine has been recognized by numerous organizations, including the National Research Council, Institute of Medicine, Computing Community Consortium, and the National Academy of Engineering. Additionally, a congressionally mandated review of Networking and Information Technology Research and Development emphasized the critical role that networking and information technology will play in spurring innovation to solve the nation's most pressing challenges, including health and healthcare.

This workshop addressed these issues through a collaboration between the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the Research Councils of the United Kingdom (RCUK). The workshop pursued the following three goals: 1) to facilitate the development of novel computational approaches to health challenges; 2) to guide data scientists in discovering and accessing NIH-funded US and RCUK-funded UK health datasets; and 3) to support early-stage researchers in establishing interdisciplinary, international collaborations. 

Methods

This workshop represented a collaboration between agencies, disciplines, and countries. The model for this workshop was to identify challenges and opportunities for Data Science, computer science and engineering advances in the health domain. The meeting design utilized two keynote presentations to frame the discussion, and in depth discussions of datasets, challenge areas, and future research opportunities to generate a research agenda informing future directions for the field. The keynote speakers and datasets of focus represented the US and UK.   Mentorship for early career investigators from more senior colleagues remained a key element throughout. The process for identifying workshop participants began with a call for proposals from early career researchers. Proposals were evaluated on the novelty and impact of the computational, data and inferential science approaches and the quality of the health challenge being addressed. Additionally, experts were selected based on their research background and expertise to provide mentorship and insight throughout the workshop.  (See Appendix for a complete list of speakers, experts and attendees.)

Specifically, the workshop was framed by two keynote presentations that identified the need and opportunity for collaboration between the Data Science and health research communities. First, Dr. Iain Buchan discussed the health data landscape and the role of data analytics in improving health. Next, Dr. Kunle Olukotun discussed recent computational advances and key surrounding scaling data analytics, especially as needed for the future of personalized medicine.

Following the keynotes, curators and leading experts of six NIH- and RCUK-funded datasets were presented an overview of each dataset and answered questions regarding data use and associated research opportunities (see Appendix for presenters). The datasets included three supported by the NIH: The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), Health and Retirement Study (HRS), and three supported by RCUK: UK Biobank, Millennium Cohort Study, and CALIBER. The datasets were selected to include a broad range of data types including clinical, genomic, behavioral, socioeconomic, and imaging data. After which, senior researchers mentored early career investigators on individual research concepts incorporating one or more of the aforementioned datasets. Next, the group transitioned into breakout sessions on broader data and analytics challenges crossing multiple datasets. The meeting concluded with a discussion of future research directions for the field and funding opportunities.  

Results

 The outcomes of the workshop were centered on computational and inferential challenges and opportunities in utilizing health datasets, indicative of the scale to come (Very Large or “Big Data”). The broad data challenges discussed included managing data sampled at varying frequencies, scaling computational methods with growing data volume, techniques to handle noisy sensor data, determining the need for novelty in computational methods, addressing transferability of analytics across datasets, and generating unbiased estimates for missing data. Preliminary small group discussions were presented to the larger group, which led to a discussion and development of the future research agenda identifying key areas for advances in Data Science for the Health domain. The identified topics for the research agenda were classified as data quality; data interoperability; performance metrics; scaling inferential methods; reasoning with heterogeneous data; collaboration; humans in the loop; modeling complex temporal data; training; and discovering data. These topics are described in detail below. 

 

Conclusion

This workshop brought together computer and data scientists, and health and clinical researchers from across the United States and the United Kingdom. While it was clear that there are troves of health data available for data scientists, it was clear they could not do the job alone. The workshop highlighted many questions that form a rich research agenda for Data Science in the area of Health. It also made apparent the need for trans-disciplinary or Convergence research that integrate Data Science and Health research to realize personalized medicine. 

 


Last Modified: 06/02/2017
Modified by: Euan Ashley

Additionally, a congressionally mandated review of Networking and Information Technology Research and Development emphasized the critical role that networking and information technology will play in spurring innovation to solve the nation's most pressing challenges, including health and healthcare. This workshop addressed these issues through a collaboration between the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the Research Councils of the United Kingdom (RCUK). Methods This workshop represented a collaboration between agencies, disciplines, and countries. The model for this workshop was to identify challenges and opportunities for Data Science, computer science and engineering advances in the health domain. The meeting design utilized two keynote presentations to frame the discussion, and in depth discussions of datasets, challenge areas, and future research opportunities to generate a research agenda informing future directions for the field. The keynote speakers and datasets of focus represented the US and UK. Mentorship for early career investigators from more senior colleagues remained a key element throughout. (See Appendix for a complete list of speakers, experts and attendees.) Specifically, the workshop was framed by two keynote presentations that identified the need and opportunity for collaboration between the Data Science and health research communities. First, Dr. Iain Buchan discussed the health data landscape and the role of data analytics in improving health. Following the keynotes, curators and leading experts of six NIH- and RCUK-funded datasets were presented an overview of each dataset and answered questions regarding data use and associated research opportunities (see Appendix for presenters). The datasets included three supported by the NIH: The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), Health and Retirement Study (HRS), and three supported by RCUK: UK Biobank, Millennium Cohort Study, and CALIBER. The datasets were selected to include a broad range of data types including clinical, genomic, behavioral, socioeconomic, and imaging data. The identified topics for the research agenda were classified as data quality; data interoperability; performance metrics; scaling inferential methods; reasoning with heterogeneous data; collaboration; humans in the loop; modeling complex temporal data; training; and discovering data. These topics are described in detail below. Conclusion This workshop brought together computer and data scientists, and health and clinical researchers from across the United States and the United Kingdom. While it was clear that there are troves of health data available for data scientists, it was clear they could not do the job alone. The workshop highlighted many questions that form a rich research agenda for Data Science in the area of Health. It also made apparent the need for trans-disciplinary or Convergence research that integrate Data Science and Health research to realize personalized medicine.
